description: Italian colonialism in the twentieth century and postcolonial legacy in recent decades through media, literary, and cinematic texts. Credit can only be applied for one of ITAL_V 378, ITST_V 378 or RMST_V 346. Equivalency: ITAL_V 378 or ITST_V 378

name: Gender and Sexuality in Italian Cinema
description: Gender and sexuality in Italian cinema within the country's historical, sociopolitical, and cultural milieus. Credit can only be applied for one of ITAL_V 379, ITST_V 379 or RMST_V 347. Equivalency: ITAL_V 379 or ITST_V 379.

name: Italian Cinema: Neorealism
description: A survey of the major classics of post-WWII Italian Neorealism in cinema emphasizing their historical, political, social, philosophical and technical contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of ITAL _V 385, ITST _V 385, or RMST _V 355. Equivalency: ITAL _V 385 or ITST _V 385

name: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Literature
description: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT_V 392 or RMST_V 361. Equivalency: PORT_V 392.

name: The Brazilian Amazon
description: Examines the complexity and diversity of the Brazilian Amazon, engaging in a variety of topics of interdisciplinary nature, with focus on the peoples, literatures and cultures of this region, and through the use of various genres.

name: Brazilian and Portuguese Cultures
description: Examines materials from a variety of cultural genres, including Lusophone cultural manifestations such as fado, futebol, samba, cuisine, telenovelas and more.

name: The Global Renaissance: Hispanic Cross-Cultural Contacts
description: Early modern (ca. 1400-1700) literature and culture. Exploration of Spain's Mediterranean, Transatlantic and Transpacific cross-cultural contacts.

name: Hopscotch: Topics in Hispanic Literature
description: Spain and Latin America's contributions to global culture through popular Hispanic literature in translation. Credit will be granted for only one of SPAN _V 312 or RMST _V 372. Equivalency: SPAN_V 312.

name: Masterpieces in Hispanic Literature
description: Literary texts from Spain and the Hispanic world. Examines their broad cultural and transnational impact on the Romance-speaking world of yesterday and today. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Mapping Gendered Spaces in Hispanic Literature and Culture
description: Examines selected topics in gender and sexuality in diverse time periods, geographical contexts, and literary genres in Spain and Latin America.

name: The Caribbean: Frontiers of the Romance World
description: Literature and culture from the island of Hispaniola (Haiti, Dominican Republic) and the French Caribbean from a comparative perspective.

name: Genre Adaptations in the Hispanic World
description: Examines adaptations of works from the Hispanic World into various literary and cultural genres (including literature to film, novel to graphic novel), considering the historical and cultural context, themes, and narrative perspectives.

name: Barcelona
description: An introduction to the city of Barcelona from a cultural studies perspective including the study of its art, literature, architecture, and social practices.

name: Romance Linguistics
description: Vocabulary, phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, and sociolinguistics of spoken and written Romance languages. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST 400 or RMST 468. Prerequisite: 2nd year standing. A beginners knowledge (CFER A1) in at least one of the Romance languages is highly recommended.

name: Visions of Nature and the Environment in the Romance World
description: History, literature and philosophy of anthropization and ecology in the Romance world. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher.

name: Studies in Romance Languages and Literature
description: Study of a literary or cultural topic that extends beyond just one of the Romance Languages. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher.

name: Italian Cinema and Its Cultural Background
description: Films with English subtitles. Course content will vary. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 452, ITST _V 432 or ITAL _V 430. Equivalency: ITAL_V 430 or ITST_V 432.

name: Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy
description: A close reading of Dante's masterpiece, along with excerpts from some of his other works: Vita Nuova, Convivio, Monarchia, Epistles. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 453, ITST _V 413 or ITAL _V 403. Equivalency: ITST _V 413 or ITAL _V 403.

name: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Middle Ages
description: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 454, ITST _V 414 or ITAL _V 404. Equivalency: ITST _V 414 or ITAL _V 404.

name: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Renaissance
description: Masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance in literature and the other arts. Authors and artists studied range from Pico to Ariosto and Machiavelli, from Botticelli to Leonardo and Michelangelo. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 455, ITST _V 415 or ITAL _V 405. Equivalency: ITAL _V 405 or ITST _V 415

name: Classics of Seventeenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
description: Classics of the Italian literature of the Mannerist and Baroque age in their intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST _V 416 or ITAL _V 406 or RMST _V 456. Equivalency: ITST _V 416 or ITAL _V 406

name: Classics of Eighteenth-Century Italian Literature and Culture
description: Classics of the Italian literature of the age of the Enlightenment in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST _V 417 or ITAL _V 407 or RMST _V 457. Equivalency: ITST _V 417 or ITAL _V 407

name: Topics in Nineteenth-century Italian Literature and Culture
description: Italian literature of the 19th century in its intellectual, socio-political, and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of ITST _V 418 or ITAL _V 408 or RMST _V 458. Equivalency: ITST _V 418 or ITAL _V 408

name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture
description: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Credit will be granted for only one of RMST _V 459, ITST _V 419 or ITAL_V 409. Recommended pre-requisite: Second-year standing or higher. Equivalency: ITST_V 419 or ITAL_V 409.

name: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Culture
description: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT_V 405 or RMST_V 460. Recommended: Second-year standing or higher. Equivalency: PORT_V 405.

name: Research Intensive Seminar in Romance Studies
Honours Essay
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Studies in Romance Languages and Cultures
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Major Essay
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Learning Russian 1
description: Introduction to the language for beginners. Ability to enjoy communicating in everyday situations and cultural contexts. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 101 or RUSS _V 100.

name: Learning Russian 2
description: Continuation of RUSS _V 101. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ . Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 102 or RUSS _V 100.

name: Learning Russian 3
description: Continuation of RUSS_V 102. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 201 or RUSS _V 200.

name: Learning Russian 4
description: Continuation of RUSS_V 201. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 202 or RUSS_V 200.

name: Russian Conversation Practice 1
description: Emphasis on the study of oral communication skills and strategies. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 208 or RUSS_V 215. Equivalency: RUSS_V 215.

name: Learning Russian 5
description: Continuation of RUSS_V 202. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 301 or RUSS_V 300.

name: Learning Russian 6
description: Continuation of RUSS_V 301. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 302 or RUSS_V 300.

name: Readings in Russophone Texts
description: Texts are selected from 19th-, 20th-, and 21stcentury sources. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 304 or RUSS_V 305. Equivalency: RUSS_V 305.

name: Russian through Film
description: Conversation and composition using Russian film. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 307 or RUSS_V 316. Equivalency: RUSS_V 316.

name: Russian Conversation Practice 2
description: Continuation of RUSS_V 208. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 308 or RUSS_V 315. Equivalency: RUSS_V 315.

name: Learning Russian through Critical Contemporary Topics
description: Discussion and analysis of current issues in a Russian-speaking seminar format. Spoken and written communication about societal topics fostering advance competence. Continuation of RUSS_V 302. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 401 or RUSS_V 400.

name: Introductory Sanskrit
description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 300 or SANS 102 or both SANS 100, SANS 101 or both SANS 301, SANS 302.

name: Introductory Sanskrit I
description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. No prior proficiency in Sanskrit required. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 301 or SANS 100 or SANS 300.

name: Introductory Sanskrit II
description: Continuation of SANS 301. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 302 or SANS 101 or SANS 300. Recommended pre-requisite: SANS 301.

name: Intermediate Sanskrit
description: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 400 or SANS 200 or both SANS 201, SANS 202 or both SANS 401, SANS 402. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SANS 300, SANS 302.

name: Intermediate Sanskrit I
description: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 401 or SANS 201 or SANS 400. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SANS 300, SANS 302.

name: Intermediate Sanskrit II
description: Continuation of SANS 401. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 402 or SANS 202 or SANS 400. Recommended pre-requisite: SANS 401.

name: Science One
description: An innovative first-year multi-disciplinary course incorporating biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics with a strong focus on the connections between these traditional disciplines. Students with credit for SCIE_V 001 will be deemed to have satisfied all BIOL_V 112, BIOL_V 121, BIOL_V 180, CHEM_V 121, CHEM_V 123, MATH_V 100, MATH_V 101, PHYS_V 117, PHYS_V 118, PHYS_V119, and PHYS_V 129 requirements. See the Science One website ( www.scienceone.ubc.ca )for further information and the application process for admission to SCIE_V 001. [12-6-4;12-6-4] Prerequisite: All of: CALC 12, ENGL 12, and Pre-calculus 12; two of: CHEM 12, PHYS 12, High School Biology (either BIOL 11 or BIOL 12). This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Science One A
description: Block registration marker for the biology, chemistry, mathematics and physics components of the Science One program. Restricted to students in the Science One program. [12-6-4] Prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12; and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12. and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.

name: First-Year Focus Seminar
description: Seminar for First-Year Focus option focused on discipline-specific learning strategies for academic success and community and scholarly engagement. This course is restricted to first-year students in the First-Year Focus option. Pass/Fail [1*-0-1*] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Pre-Calculus Mathematics
description: Algebra, functions and graphing, expone ntial and logarithmic functions, trigonometry. Restricted to students enrolled in the Indigenous STEM Bridging Pathway. [3-0-1] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: First-Year Seminar in Science
description: Small-group experience where students study science in society, scientific process, and how to communicate scientific concepts. Enrolment limited to students in the B. Sc. program in Science. [3-0-0] This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Topics in Sustainability Science
description: Topics in sustainability, based on concepts introduced in first-year Science courses. [1-0-0] Corequisite: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121. Restricted to students with first-year standing in Science.

name: Communicating Science
description: Effective communication and presentation skills in science. [1-0-3] Corequisite: One of BIOL_V 300, STAT_V 200, STAT_V 241 and 3rd or 4th year standing in Combined Major in Science.

name: Socio-Ecological Systems Research
description: Research design and methods for socio-ecological systems research. Students work directly with faculty mentors to conduct research on contemporary topics such as climate resilience, food security, and environmental sustainability. [1.5-0-1] Prerequisite: Third-year standing and instructor's permission

name: Discipline-based Education Research Methodology
description: Overview of methodological approaches to education research in disciplines having natural, physical, and life-science foundations. Prerequisite: Third-year standing and permission of the instructor. Equivalency: SCIE500

name: Sustainability for Community and the World
description: Explores systems thinking in the context of sustainability and also re-examines the familiar three pillar model of sustainability - society, ecology, and economics - highlighting its uses and limitations. [3-0-0] Prerequisite: One of ASIC 200, ASIC 220, APBI 260, APBI 265, ARCL 309, BIOL 230, CHEM 301, CHEM 302, CHEM 341, CIVL 200, CONS 330, ECON 210, ENDS 221, ENVR 200, ENVR 300, EOSC 270, EOSC 340, EOSC 345, FRST 100, GEOG 211, GEOG 310, HIST 106, ISCI 360, ISCI 361, LAW 386, LFS 250, PHYS 333, POLI 351, PSYC 321, PSYC 421, SCIE 120, SCIE 320. Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

name: Discipline-based Education Research Methodology
description: Overview of methodological approaches to education research in disciplines having natural, physical, and life-science foundations. Equivalency: SCIE 400 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: SCIE_V 596. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: SCIE_V 597. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Restricted to students admitted to the Master of Science Co-operative Education Option or Doctor of Philosophy Co-operative Education Option. Pass/Fail. Prerequisite: SCIE_V 598. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Integration Project
description: Design, analysis, and implementation of technology to create a bench-scale smart grid energy system. Assessment of technology based on sustainability, market, policy and regulatory considerations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Renewable and Efficient Electric Power Systems
description: Electricity infrastructure, fundamentals of electric power, solar photovoltaic systems, wind electric conversion systems, other renewable energy systems, grid integration of renewables, smart grid, distributed energy resources, electricity storage. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Topics in Power and Energy
description: Current topics in smart grid systems and technologies in the context of sustainability, market, policy and regulation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Smart Grid Communication Systems
description: Review of probability theory, signals and noise, spectral analysis; information theory and applications; detection and estimation of signals in the presence of noise; performance calculations of modulation systems; digital communication techniques. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 531 or ELEC 431. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Power Electronic Devices
description: New devices and applications in power electronics with applications to smart grid systems. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 550 or EECE 550. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Architecture for Learning Systems
description: Learning in neural networks, error backpropagation, simulated annealing, content addressable memories. Data representation topics. Implementation challenges in real world scale problems. Architectures for function approximation in Reinforcement Learning. Comparison with conventional artificial intelligence: history and emerging trends. Credit will be granted for only one of SGES 592 or EECE 592. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Introduction to Slavic and Eastern European Cultures
description: Cultural developments from the medieval period to the present. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 120 or SLAV_V 105. Equivalency: SLAV_V 105.

name: Introduction to Slavic Languages and Communication
description: Insights into Slavic languages in their shared and diverse cultural, social, literary, and political contexts over time. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ .

name: Nineteenth-Century Russophone Literature
description: Major works and writers in the Russian tradition of the 19th century. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 241 or RUSS_V 206. Equivalency: RUSS_V 206.

name: Contemporary Russophone Literature
description: Literature written in Russian, in and beyond Russia, from the 20th and 21st century. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 207 or SLAV_V 242. Equivalency: RUSS_V 207.

name: War and Peace in Slavic and Eastern European Life
description: Languages, discourses, and art forms which reflect present-day life in Slavic and Eastern European countries where violent conflicts, transformed by technologies, blur the boundaries between war and peace. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ .

name: Polish Literature and Film
description: Selected films and translated literature by Polish writers and filmmakers, with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 424 or POLS_V 424. Equivalency: POLS_V 424.

name: The Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film
description: The Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of SLAV_V 433 or POLS_V 426. Equivalency: POLS_V 426

name: Tolstoy
description: Works, influence and critical reception of Leo Tolstoy. Find out more at https://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS_V 411 or SLAV_V 447. Equivalency: RUSS_V 411.

name: Dostoevsky
description: Works, influence and critical reception of Fyodor Dostoevsky. Find out more at ttps://cenes.ubc.ca/courses/ Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS _V 412 or SLAV_V 448. Equivalency: RUSS_V 412

name: Khichri: The South Asian Languages of Vancouver
description: A systematic introduction to the grammars and scripts of Hindi, Urdu, Punjabi and Sanskrit, primarily through the media of Indo-Canadian popular culture (film, radio, bhangra, etc.)

name: Introduction to Sociology
description: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 100 or both SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Social Interaction and Culture
description: Culture, identity, social interaction, relationships and socialization. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 101 or SOCI 100.

name: Inequality and Social Change
description: Inequality, institutions, social structure and social change. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 102 or SOCI 100.

name: Sociology of Family
description: An introduction to contemporary family forms and relations.

name: Ethnicity
description: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors.

name: Global Population Dynamics
description: Core processes that influence world population patterns and trends.

name: Canadian Social Structure
description: Descriptive and analytic survey of such features as demographic characteristics, class structure, ethnicity, and regional variation in Canadian society as a basis for understanding current social issues.

name: Research Methods
description: Introduction to research designs and methodologies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Sociology of Indigenous Peoples
description: Sociological perspective of Indigenous peoples and issues both internationally and within Canada.

name: Sociology of Personal Life
description: A sociological examination of everyday life exploring the social in the personal.

name: Shopping, Society, and Sustainability
description: Major theories of consumer society, evaluating impacts of shopping on human and non-human environments and popular solutions to these impacts.

name: Introduction to Social Interaction
description: Research on social interaction, with an emphasis on group (as opposed to individual) processes and behaviour.

name: Crime and Society
description: Crime as a social phenomenon, with emphasis on the changing definitions of crime in relation to social and political change in Canadian and other societies.

name: Work and Society
description: Social forces responsible for changing patterns of technological innovation and work organization in modern industrial societies. Emphasis on the organization of work, labour force dynamics, and technological change.

name: Sociology of Creativity
description: The application of sociological concepts to the examination of creative processes.

name: Data and Society
description: Impacts of changing information and communication technologies on societies and social interactions.

name: Health and Society
description: An introduction to health and illness through a sociological lens. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Citizenship and Identity
description: The concepts of citizenship, identity, and human rights as social processes shaping individuals and communities (both local and global).

name: Global Pandemics
description: Global pandemics in relation to social inequality, social interaction and social institutions.

name: Sociology of Development and Underdevelopment
description: Processes of social change in the Third World and other developing countries. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Ethnic and Racial Inequality
description: A critical examination of classical and contemporary theories and research evidence concerning ethnic and racial inequality at the societal and interpersonal levels. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology of Migration
description: Sociological approaches to the movement of peoples and its impact over time. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Canadian Society
description: Social organization of Canadian society: relationships between social institutions and social processes (e.g., economics, education, family, law, media, and politics); including issues of ancestry, ethnicity, gender, region, and social class. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Gender Relations
description: The nature of gender relations, their social and cultural expression, and theories of gender inequality. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology of Masculinity
description: How masculinity differs across social contexts and time periods. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Diversity in Family Forms
description: An examination of diversity within and between families and of diverse family forms. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Sociology of the Life Course
description: Individuals and families through the life course. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Social Statistics I
description: The testing of sociological theories using quantitative data analysis techniques on numerical data from social surveys, experiments and official statistics. SOCI 328 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Credit Exclusion List ( https://vancouver.calendar.ubc.ca/faculties-colleges-and-schools/facultâ€¦ ) before registering. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology of Adornment
description: The application of sociological concepts to the understanding of objects that we use to adorn our bodies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI_V 100, SOCI_V 101, SOCI_V 102

name: Consumers and Consumption
description: The structure and culture of consuming and consumption. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology of Aging
description: Demographic, economic, and social trends associated with aging, ageism, and aging populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 344 and SOCI 444. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: SOCI 444.

name: Work and Inequality
description: The meaning of work and leisure, properties of work organization, the division of labour, and the relation of work and social inequality. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Community Studies
description: Study of the organization of human communities; a focus upon collective activities including family, work, neighbourhood, and formal and informal networks. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology and Natural Resources
description: Sociological perspectives on property, resource industries (such as agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining), resource development, and resource communities. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Social Inequality
description: Tendencies toward equality and inequality; manifestations of inequality (occupation, education, gender, ethnicity, income, power) and their consequences; caste and class features of major stratification systems; theories of social class; stratification profile of contemporary industrial societies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Built Environments
description: Physical, social, and economic aspects of built environments, including housing and community planning. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology of Sexualities
description: Historical and social construction of sexual identities, desires, communities, and politics in the twentieth century. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches
description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 370 or both SOCI 371, SOCI 372. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Classical Traditions in Theory
description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems and topics in the foundational theories of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 371 or SOCI 370. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Contemporary Directions in Theory
description: A survey of theories in contemporary sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 372 or SOCI 370. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociological Methods: Survey Research
description: Questionnaire design, interviewing, sampling, and analysis of survey data. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 217.

name: Sociological Methods: Experimental Research
description: Research strategies associated with the implementation of experimental methods in sociology. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

name: Sociological Methods: Qualitative Research
description: Examination of the different traditions of qualitative sociological inquiry and the associated methodological features used to study the interpretive practices and meanings in the everyday lives of individuals. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

name: Sociological Methods: Historical Research
description: Methodological problems and research strategies associated with the interpretation of socio-historical data; contributions of classical and contemporary approaches to historical sociology and social history. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

name: Sociology of Health and Illness
description: Classic and contemporary sociological perspectives on health, illness, and health care. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Drugs and Society
description: Social dimensions of the causes, consequences, regulation, and treatment of substance use from Canadian and international perspectives. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Feminist Theory
description: The emergence of feminist theory, its relationship to sociology, and the major theoretical schools of thought. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Social Statistics II
description: Primary emphasis on applications of statistical techniques to data in Sociology. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 328.

name: Sociology of the Environment
description: Sociological approaches to the study of environmental conflicts, issues, movements, impact of changing technology, economic development on the environment. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology of Food
description: Cultural, economic, and political aspects of food production and consumption, including connections to class, ethnicity, and gender. Food-related social movements will be included. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Urban Sociology
description: Demographic, behavioural, and organizational aspects of urban structures and of urbanization in different societies and periods. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Global Citizenship
description: Sociology approaches to global citizenship, including its contested nature and intellectual lineage.

name: Economic Sociology
description: Analysis of economic actions and institutions using the concepts and methods of sociology. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Society, Economy and Family
description: The study of family in social and economic contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 and FMST 440. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: FMST 440

name: Families and Work
description: The effect of combining family and work roles. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 442 and FMST 442. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200. Equivalency: FMST 442.

name: Honours Tutorial
description: Requires the presentation of at least one research paper. Restricted to students in the Sociology Honours program. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Political Sociology
description: The social and economic bases of political power, including the study of the state, ideology, political movements, revolutions, and political violence. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Social Movements
description: A study of the sources, stages, and effects of social movements in developing and modernized societies. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology of the Arts
description: An examination of the arts as social practices from the standpoint of the relationships among artists, critics, patrons, and public; and the social institutions through which these relationships are structured. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology of Education
description: Examines the role of schooling in modern society including links with inequality, knowledge production, socialization and the economy. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Queer Theory and Politics
description: Empirical expressions and political possibilities of queer theory. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 369.

name: Sociology of Crime and Justice
description: Critical examination of specific forms of crime in relation to the criminal justice system including law, enforcement, and corrections. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology of Mental Illness
description: A sociological approach to the meaning of mental illness; the organization of psychiatric treatment; problems in the explanation of the distribution of mental illness in a population. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Sociology of Soccer
description: Soccer and colonialism, soccer and global politics, and inequalities in soccer by gender, sexuality, race and class. Prerequisite: One of SOCI_V 100, SOCI_V 101, SOCI_V 102.

name: Social Determinants of Health
description: Relationships between social phenomena (e.g., personal beliefs, lifestyle practices, social support, socio-economic status, social class, gender, and ethnicity) and the health of human populations. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Contemporary Chinese Society
description: Current social topics in Chinese society; perspectives on gender, inequality, culture, and social relations. Prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Foundations of Sociological Thought
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Contemporary Sociological Theory
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Research Design and Techniques (Quantitative)
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Research Design and Techniques (Qualitative)
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Methodology of Social Inquiry
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Cross-National Comparisons in the Social Sciences
description: Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 511 or IAR 511. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 511 or IAR 511. Equivalency: IAR 511 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Theories About the Family
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Analyzing Quantitative Data in Sociology
description: Prerequisite: SOCI 502 is a prerequisite for Sociology graduate students. A background in material such as that covered in SOCI 502 is highly recommended for all others. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Qualitative Data Analysis in Sociology
description: Prerequisite: SOCI 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Graduate Seminar
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Advanced Soil Processes
description: Integrating the environmental factors influencing soil-forming processes and their ecological implications. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 501 or APBI 401. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Advanced Sustainable Soil Management
description: Integration of fundamental, unifying, soil science principles in sustainable ecosystem management. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 502 or APBI 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Advanced Soil Sampling, Analyses and Data Interpretation
description: Field and laboratory analytical techniques in the chemical, biological and physical assessment of soils. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 503 or APBI 403. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Watershed Science
description: Watershed evaluation, key aspects of hydrology, water quality, land use impacts on water resources and integration of multiple land use activities and their cumulative impacts. Equivalency: LWS 515 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Urban Watershed Management
description: Urbanization impacts on water resources with a focus on rainwater management, water quality, point and non-point sources of pollution, drinking water and waste water, riparian buffer zones, cumulative effects, and application of beneficial management practices. Equivalency: LWS516 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Land and Water Resource Evaluation
description: Topics in land and water system evaluations and assessing resource development options; monitoring and modelling environmental systems. Equivalency: LWS 517. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Water in International Development
description: Key water issues associated with international development: global water demand, scarcity, efficiency of use, water as a commodity, biophysical and policy aspects of water management, water and health, land use impact, water harvesting, improved irrigation, and pollution prevention. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Agricultural Watershed Management
description: Intensive and extensive agriculture with a focus on water needs, water use, and impacts on water resources. Non-point sources of pollution, nutrient modelling, soil and land degradation, protection, and rehabilitation of watersheds including buffer zones, wetlands, and best management practices. Equivalency: LWS520 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Instrumentation for Biometeorology
description: The theory, design and evaluation of instrumentation for biometeorological research. Prerequisite: Permission of the instructor is required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Master's Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Introduction to Social Welfare
description: An introduction to the perspectives, concepts and theoretical foundations of social welfare, including an analysis of the institutional structures of social welfare in the modern state.

name: Introduction to Social Work Practice
description: An introduction to the knowledge, skills and values of social work practice in its many forms, emphasizing different ways of understanding the context of social and personal problems. Prerequisite: SOWK200

name: Practicum I
description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail. Corequisite: SOWK 310. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
description: Integrates students' learning from field, practice, policy and theory courses for the purposes of professional development.

name: Indigenous Peoples and Critical Social Work Analysis
description: Contemporary social issues facing Indigenous peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Settler-Canadian/Indigenous relations; the impact of Settler-Canadian institutions upon Indigenous peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 325 or 425. Enrolment is limited to students in the BSW program.

name: Culture and Race in Social Work Practice
description: Issues and problems inherent in practising social work in diverse cultural settings.

name: Canadian Social Policy
description: Analysis of race, gender, class and culture as factors in the distribution and delivery of Canadian social benefits and social services.

name: Social Work Practice II
description: This course examines the principles of optimal social work process with individuals, small groups, families and larger collectivities.

name: Practicum II
description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Advanced Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
description: Development of professional judgement, evaluation, and self-evaluation in practice.

name: Introduction to Social Work Research
description: Theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. Development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 420 or 320. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Social Context of Child Development
description: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 or FMST 441. Equivalency: FMST 441

name: Policy and Practice in Child Welfare
description: Covers the statutory bases and practices associated with the continuum of child welfare services from prevention through permanency planning.

name: Social Work Practice in Community Mental Health
description: Online course providing overview of social work services to persons with a mental illness. Prerequisite: Fourth-year standing in SOWK. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Health Care Team Development
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the skills, knowledge, roles, and issues involved with working successfully in interprofessional health and human service teams. Intended for upper division students in any health and human service program. Offered as IHHS 400 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 451 or IHHS 400. Equivalency: IHHS 400.

name: HIV Prevention and Care
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course prepares senior students to respond effectively to the HIV epidemic and its consequences. The knowledge and skills required for interprofessional and discipline-specific work are explored. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Offered as IHHS 402 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 452 or IHHS 402. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Disability and Justice
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course considers how health and human service professionals can effectively practice with people with disabilities from a social justice perspective. Social and personal context and practice responses are examined. Offered as IHHS 407 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 453 or IHHS 407.

name: Interdisciplinary Practice with Children and Families
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers interprofessional perspectives, challenges, and strategies. Clinical experience and some knowledge of child protection issues required. Offered as IHHS 403 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 454 or IHHS 403.

name: Palliative Care
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers attitudes, knowledge, skills, and abilities necessary for interprofessional and discipline-specific work in palliative care. For students registered in health and human service programs only. Offered as IHHS 405 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 455 or IHHS 405.

name: Advanced Canadian Social Policy
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Social Work Practice
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Communication Skills in Social Work Practice
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Social Analysis for Social Work Practice
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Directed Field Studies in Social Work I
description: Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: First Nations Social Issues
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Foundation MSW Integrative Seminar
description: Development of professional judgment, critical reflection, and integration of theory, practice, research and policy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Social Work Practice in Addictions
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Family Mediation and Conflict Resolution
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Advanced Social Work Practice: Mental Health
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Social Work Practice in the Field of Aging
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Graduating Essay
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Social Work and Social Justice
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Health and Social Care Praxis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Advanced Integrative Seminar
description: Advanced development of professional judgment, critical reflection, and integration of theory, practice, research, policy. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Social Work Doctoral Seminar
description: Critical examination of research, teaching, proposal writing and publication. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Social Theory, Ideology and Ethics
description: Critical analysis of major social theories, differentiating competing approaches to understanding human behaviour; social theory, social ideology, and social ethics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Advanced Data Analysis in Social Work
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Advanced Qualitative Inquiry
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Beginners' Spanish I
description: Fundamentals of the Spanish language. Communicate with basic vocabulary in common tasks and situations related to present and future events. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives. Credit will be granted for either SPAN 103 or both SPAN 101, SPAN 102.

name: Beginners' Spanish II
description: Continuation of foundational elements of the language. Communicate using essential vocabulary in common tasks and situations related to past, present and future events. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives. Credit will be granted for either SPAN 103 or both SPAN 101, SPAN 102. Recommended pre-requisite: SPAN 101.

name: Intensive Beginners' Spanish
description: Fundamentals of the Spanish language. Ideal for students with Spanish 12 or expertise in another Romance language. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives. Credit will be granted for SPAN 103 or both SPAN 101, SPAN 102. Prerequisite: Grade 12 Spanish or for native or near-native speakers of other Romance Languages.

name: Elementary Spanish I
description: Expansion of fundamentals. Enhanced ability to exchange information, discuss the past and future, and express wishes, hopes and feelings in common personal and social contexts. Aligned with CEFR level A1-A2 objectives. Credit will be granted for either SPAN 203 or both SPAN 201, SPAN 202. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SPAN 102, SPAN 103, SPAN 11.

name: Elementary Spanish II
description: Expansion of fundamental notions and presentation of more elaborate structures in a variety of tenses and modes. Communicate to explore Hispanic culture and to hypothesize about present and past situations. Aligned with CEFR level A2 objectives. Credit will be granted for either SPAN 203 or both SPAN 201, SPAN 202. Recommended pre-requisite: SPAN 201.

name: Intensive Elementary Spanish
description: Continuation of SPAN 103. Aligned with CEFR level A2 objectives. Credits will be granted for SPAN 203 or both SPAN 201, SPAN 202. Recommended pre-requisites: one of SPAN 103, SPAN 102, or placement test for native or near-native speakers of other Romance Languages.

name: Conversational Spanish I
description: Emphasizes communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; developing oral fluency and listening comprehension, through discussion of written texts and films. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community. Prerequisite: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, or SPAN 203.

name: Conversational Spanish II
description: Builds on communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; exploration of cultural topics through discussion of written texts and other media. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community. Aligned with CEFR A2 objectives. Prerequisite: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or SPAN 206.

name: Conversational Spanish and Culture
description: Exploration of cultural topics, concepts, and practices and how they frame and relate to the diverse geographies and cultural traditions from Spain, Latin America, and the diaspora through oral and written expressions. This course is recommended for students who have completed SPAN_V 202 or SPAN_V 203.

name: Introduction to Hispanic Literature
description: Major texts, authors, periods, and genres of Hispanic literature; key concepts, terminology, and practices of literary analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish literature courses. Prerequisite: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203, or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: Introduction to Hispanic Culture
description: Media, figures, periods, and genres of Hispanic culture; key concepts, theories, and practices of cultural analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish culture courses. Prerequisite: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: Intermediate Spanish I
description: Complex grammatical structures in context to enhance proficiency. Explores relevant cultural topics through reading, writing, and discussion. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives. Prerequisite: One of BC High School Spanish Grade 12, SPAN 202, SPAN 203, SPAN 206, SPAN 207 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: Intermediate Spanish II
description: Expansion of and reflection on the use of complex grammatical structures in context to broaden lexical repertoire. Enhances proficiency through reading, writing, and discussion of relevant cultural topics. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives. Prerequisite: SPAN 301 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: Conversational Spanish for Advanced Speakers
description: Expands the comprehension and communicative skills of upper-level students and heritage speakers through topics drawn from Hispanic culture and current events. Aligned with CEFR B1 objectives. Prerequisite: One of SPAN 206, 207, 302, or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: Spanish for Business
description: Language of commerce, finance, marketing, and economics. Competence in business practices of the Hispanic world. Prerequisite: One of SPAN 206, 207, 301, 302 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: Business Spanish of International Trade in the Hispanic World (in Spanish)
description: Language of international commerce through real world business practices in the Hispanic world; key issues concerning business practices, engaging with real-world materials, and interacting with professionals specializing in trade with the Hispanic world. Pre-requisites: One of SPAN 206, 207, 301, 302, 308. Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: Literatures and Cultures of Spain: From Medieval to Present
description: Spanish Literature from the Middle Ages to Present. Literary analysis of narrative, poetic, dramatic, essay and other texts by considering the main literary genres and trends as well as historical and cultural context. This course is recommended for students who have completed SPAN_V 221 or SPAN_V 301.

name: Literatures and Cultures of Latin America: From Pre-Columbian to Present
description: Explore a diverse range of texts, themes and genres of Latin American literature from pre-Columbian times to present day. This course is recommended for students who have completed SPAN_V 221 or SPAN_V 301.

name: Tradition and Diversity in Spanish History and Culture
description: Conservation and progress on the Iberian Peninsula, from the Middle Ages to the present. Includes the first modern European state and its diverse cultures. Prerequisite: One of SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: Dependency and Revolution in Latin American History and Culture
description: Continuities and changes in the Americas from before Columbus to the present. Includes the first modern global empire and its ambivalent legacies. Prerequisite: SPAN 202, SPAN 203 or successful completion of language placement exam or an assessment interview.

name: The Golden Age of Peninsular Literature and Culture
description: Tradition, faith, conflict, prosperity, and decadence in literature and everyday life from the Middle Ages to 1700. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Divergent Visions: Peninsular Literature and Culture since 1700
description: Modern Spanish literature and culture, from Empire to the European Union. Includes Romanticism, Modernism, Republicanism, and Separatism. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Colonial Encounters in Spanish-American Literature and Culture
description: Spanish colonialism in the Americas from the Conquest to the 1820's and the dawn of Independence. Includes coloniality, hybridity, subalternity, and autonomy. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Modern Magics: Spanish-American Literature and Culture since the 1820s
description: Literary engagements with modernity in the Spanish Americas, from the 1820's to the present. Includes civilization, progress, politicization, and violence. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Upper Intermediate Spanish I
description: Strengthening fluency and accuracy in spoken and written communication. Emphasis on mediation, interpretation, and metalinguistic competencies through translation and comparative stylistics. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Upper Intermediate Spanish II
description: Continued strengthening of fluency, accuracy, and spontaneity in spoken and written communication. Emphasis on contextualized grammar and vocabulary; critical reading and discussion of texts. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: History of the Spanish Language
description: Major features of the development of the Spanish language, from its origins to the present. Includes the history of Spanish phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and dialectology. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Breaking the Mold: Gender Representation(s) in Hispanic Literature and Culture
description: Gender and sexuality in Spain and Latin America. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: From Text to Stage: Topics in Hispanic Theatre
description: Selected areas of study relating to Hispanic Theatre. Consult the Department for this year's offerings. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN 221; and SPAN 301 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Hispanic Linguistics
description: Spanish as a linguistic system. Includes the structure of Spanish words and sentences, dialectal varieties in both Spain and Latin America, and linguistic theory. Recommended pre-requisites: SPAN_V 302 or equivalent expertise in written and spoken Spanish.

name: Master's Thesis
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Doctoral Dissertation
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Sustainable Bioproducts Processing
description: Properties and characterization of macromolecules including rheology. Polymer processing and application to green products development including from lignocellulosic sources. Circular economy driven processing. Biomimetics engineering. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Sustainable Bioenergy and Biorefinery
description: Understanding technology of deriving biofuels and chemical feedstocks from forest biomass. Relating chemistry of biomass for production of liquid, solid and gaseous fuels. Processing options for value-added chemicals. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Design Laboratory for New Ventures in the Chemical Industry
description: Commercialization of chemical and biochemical products and manufacturing processes; technology development; intellectual property; budgeting and grants; with a focus on venture creation, sustainability and environmental responsibility. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Technology Commercialization for the Manufacturing Industries
description: Creation and leadership of new ventures for scale-up and commercialization of manufacturing processes, with a special emphasis on the chemical and ancillary industries. Includes assessment of manufacturing processes; techno-economic analyses; scaling up and de-risking processes; intellectual property; market penetration that are specific to the manufacturing sector. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
description: The idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. [3-0-0]

name: Working in Global Health
description: Planning/preparing for work in global health, with attention to health inequities and determinants internationally and domestically, the pursuit of partnerships to address this, power imbalances and ethical principles for carrying out this work. Health Science background not essential.

name: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
description: The idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. [3-0-0]

name: Topics in Health Informatics for Health/Life Sciences Students
description: Basic literacy in health informatics. Innovative approaches to healthcare implementation, access to care, and data utilization.

name: Environmental Impacts on Human Health
description: Harmful environmental exposures in water, air, food; aspects of environment that are beneficial for health; environmental justice; emerging environmental health threats; how epidemiology and risk assessment inform public health policy and practice.

name: Canadian Health Care Policy
description: Features of the Canadian health care system, stages in the evolution of Medicare, and how institutions, interests, and ideas shape health care policies.

name: Basic Epidemiology for Infection Control
description: Epidemiology, study, design and analysis, and outbreak investigation as it applies to institutional infection control. Equivalency: PATH 477

name: Indigenous Health: Historical Impacts and Contemporary Approaches
description: This course covers an epistemological approach that considers the social determinants of health and Indigenous spiritual-environmental and cultural perspectives and approaches to health and wellness.

name: Aging from an Interdisciplinary Perspective
description: Population and Public Health issues associated with aging.

name: Topics in Aboriginal Health: Community-based Learning Experience
description: In-depth cultural and interprofessional learning experience that enables students to live and study in BC First Nations communities while learning about health, wellness, and community strengths from a local perspective.

name: International Indigenous Experiences of Colonization
description: Interprofessional, comparative inquiry of Indigenous experiences of global colonization and the manifestations of that experience in the contemporary socio-cultural environment. Informed and guided by Indigenous knowledge and drawing upon a range of disciplines.

name: Improving Public Health: An Interprofessional Approach to Designing and Implementing Effective Interventions
description: Improving public health by developing the skills to design and deliver pragmatic, effective health behavior change interventions.

name: Violence Across the Lifespan
description: Overview of violence across the lifespan. Epidemiology, dynamics, health effects, intervention and prevention.

name: Analytical Methods in Epidemiological Research
description: Basic epidemiological designs as a framework for commonly used biostatistical techniques such as the Mantel-Haenszel, chi-squared, linear and logistic regression, and survival analysis. Computer packages will be available for computation of assignments. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502 or (b) all of SPPH 521, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 567, SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Analysis of Longitudinal Data from Epidemiological Studies
description: To explore and compare methods of analyzing continuous and categorical longitudinal data. The issues of missing data and errors in measurement/misclassification will be covered in depth. Prerequisite: Either (a) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 or (b) all of SPPH 521, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502, SPPH 567. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Epidemiological Methods 1
description: Sources and uses of epidemiologic data for health services planning and administration including methods of data collection and study design. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Epidemiological Methods 2
description: Critical thinking in epidemiology; principles and methods of study design; context for epidemiological investigations of human health. Prerequisite: SPPH 502 and one of SPPH 400 or SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Application of Epidemiological Methods
description: This second level course will teach research trainees to apply methods taught in prior courses towards the development of a fundable research protocol and the analysis and interpretation of real epidemiologic data. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502, SPPH 503. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Scientific Basis for Epidemiological Thinking
description: The course will provide a framework for students to use epidemiological and other scientific evidence to make decisions about causation and to recommend policy actions. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Quantitative Research Methods
description: Major quantitative research designs, measurement reliability and validity, common data sources used, internal and external validity, research proposals, and peer review. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: M.P.H. Practicum
description: Applied epidemiology and biostatistics in a field setting. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Genetic Epidemiology
description: Human genetics and genomics, behavioural, social, and environmental factors in modifying or influencing genetics in the manifestation of disease. Prerequisite: SPPH 502 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Survey Methods in Health Measurement
description: Concepts and techniques of measurement in epidemiological research. Topics covered include validity, reliability and misclassification, scale design and the construction of questionnaires and indices for both health outcomes and exposures. Prerequisite: One of SPPH 400, SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Cancer Control and Epidemiology
description: Collection and analysis of epidemiological data on cancer; genetic, occupational, and other risk factors; analytic techniques; cancer control, prevention, screening, early detection, and policy issues. Prerequisite: SPPH 502. or equivalent. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: The Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials
description: Ethical considerations, intention-to-treat versus efficacy trials, principles of sampling and exclusion, methods of allocation and techniques of randomization, parallel versus cross over design, monitoring treatment outcomes, adverse effects, stopping rules, analytic techniques and data interpretation, and logistical issues in the management of clinical trials. Prerequisite: One of SPPH 502, SPPH 513. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Clinical Epidemiology
description: Principles and methods of epidemiology are applied to clinical problems. Evaluation and design of laboratory and clinical tests and of therapeutic interventions. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Decision Analysis in Health Care
description: Methods and application of decision analysis to improve health from the perspective of the policy maker, health professional, and patient. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Surveillance and Monitoring in Public Health
description: Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Methods for Systematic Reviews in Health Research
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Clinical Research methods for Surgical Procedures
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Mathematical Modelling of Communicable Diseases
description: Application of mathematical models in understanding communicable disease dynamics and control; interpretation of model outcomes; modelling methods and their applications. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Qualitative Methods in Health Research Design
description: Purposes, context, procedures, and relationships within qualitative health research and methodologies. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Control of Communicable Disease
description: Epidemiology of viral, bacterial and parasitic infections with emphasis on the control of these infections in human populations. Immunization programs will be stressed. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Statistics for Health Research
description: Planned collection, numeric and graphic summarization, elementary statistical analysis of data. Examples from health sciences illustrate standard techniques for parametric and nonparametric hypothesis testing; regression and correlation; contingency tables. Also randomization, "blindfolding" and other specifically biomedical topics in statistics. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 400 or SPPH 521. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Topics in Environmental Health
description: Role of air, water, food and solid waste as sources of human health risks; global environmental health issues; sustainability. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Global Health and Human Security
description: Global threats to human health stemming from conflict, poverty, and environmental degradation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Core Biological Concepts of Public Health Practice
description: Cell biology, microbiology, molecular science, genetics, physiology, and evolution. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Issues and Concepts in Public Health
description: History of public health research and practice; occupational and environmental health; health services and systems; social and lifecourse determinants of health; and population health and emerging trends. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Leadership in Public Health
description: Organizational structure; engaging others in an organization; inter-organizational networking; building coalitions; identification of opportunities to bring change to organizations through knowledge development, management, synthesis, and implementation. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Social Determinants of Health
description: Foundational thinking giving rise to the concept of population health. Overview of the current state of research. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Rural and Remote Health
description: Issues and solutions to delivery of health services to underserved rural populations. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH_V 400 or (b) SPPH_V 521; and SPPH_V 502. Corequisite: SPPH_V 500 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Major Essay
description: Required for all M.H.Sc. students. Pass/Fail. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Epidemiology of Occupational and Environmental Health
description: Design and analysis of etiologic research in occupational health. Prerequisite: SPPH 502. or permission of the instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Health Care Systems Analysis
description: Theory, concepts, measurement, and practical skills using administrative data for analysis of health care systems. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Environmental Health Risk Assessment and Communication
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Toxicology and Public Health
description: Mechanism of action of commonly encountered occupational toxic agents; relevance of laboratory and epidemiological evidence. Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Occupational Health and Illness Processes
description: Occupational diseases; research, historical perspectives, and surveillance. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Principles of Occupational and Environmental Hygiene
description: Scientific basis for the recognition, evaluation, and control of chemical, physical, and biological, exposures; standard setting; exposure monitoring methods. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Aboriginal People and Public Health: Ethics, Policy, and Practice
description: Experience of colonization; Indian Act; the histories and intergenerational impact of the residential school; child-welfare systems; communicable disease prevention; the challenge of ethical public health practice; and traditional healing. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Perinatal Epidemiology
description: Indicators of maternal/newborn well-being across population subgroups, changing trends in obstetrical intervention, perinatal morbidity, and the analysis of perinatal data. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. Corequisite: SPPH 500 Equivalency: OBST 507 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Application of Ethical Theories in the Practice of Public Health
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Epidemiology of Aging and Chronic Diseases
description: Biology of aging, epidemiology of cardiovascular disease, neoplasms, osteoporosis and fractures, psychosocial factors and health in old age, dementias, functional status, and prevention of disease. Prerequisite: SPPH 502, SPPH 524 This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Program Planning and Evaluation
description: Examines the concept of evaluation in health services and how various methodological approaches can be used in evaluative studies. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Economic Evaluation
description: Economic evaluation of health service interventions and programs, with emphasis on methods and components of program costing. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Canadian Health Policy
description: Analysis of the evolution and structure of the Canadian health care system. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Health Technology Assessment for Health Policy
description: This course is an advanced program evaluation course. Prerequisite: SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Social Determinants of Health Across the Life Course
description: The social determinants of health have profound impacts on inequities across the life course, as do population-level interventions. Builds on SPPH 527, with an emphasis on life course perspectives and vulnerable populations. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Community Health Promotion
description: Practice and community-based (participatory) research related to health promotion, including its historical and philosophical roots. Application of social and behavioural theories to participatory research and the planning, implementation, and evaluation of community health promotion initiatives. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Introduction to Health Economics
description: Broad understanding of the health system and health system change from an economics perspective, with a focus on delivery, organization, and financing of healthcare. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Health Care Priority Setting
description: Resource allocation, economics and ethics based approaches for decision making, uptake of evidence to inform resource use in health care. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Knowledge to Action in Population Health
description: This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Advanced Economic Evaluation in Health Care
description: Economic evaluation of health technologies, considering, in detail, the policy context for the use of economic evaluation. Prerequisite: SPPH 541. Or equivalent training. Equivalency: PHAR 560. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Public Health Approaches to Substance Use and Addictions
description: Critical examination of strategies regarding addictive behaviours, substance use and related problems, in the context of a multi-disciplinary approach. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Pharmacoepidemiology
description: Principles and applications of pharmacoepidemiology. Practical skills in designing, conducting, and appraising studies of medications in large populations. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 551 or PHAR 561. Prerequisite: Previous coursework in statistics or biostatistics. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Science and Risk Communication for Public Health
description: Theory and practice of risk communication in public health, basic principles underlying effective science communication with peers, the media, and the public. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Foundations of Public Health Computing
description: Data gathering, cleaning, analysis, and visualization to produce key results using statistical software. Prerequisite: Either (a) SPPH 400 or (b) SPPH 521; and SPPH 502. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Addiction and Mental Health
description: Severe addiction and mental illness and the systemic context in which they occur. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Principles and Practices of Injury Prevention
